title: World’s Longest Tunnels (Operational)
subtitle: List of the longest operational tunnels worldwide, including type, location, length and year opened.

data.notes: 4.1 m in diameter (13.2 m2). New York City's main water supply tunnel.
16 m2 cross section. Main water supply tunnel for the Helsinki metropolitan area in southern Finland, drilled through solid rock.
Suzhou Metro Line 11 and Line 3 are connected at Weiting station with through trains operating. Longest metro tunnel
8 m in diameter (50 m2 cross section)
Longest continuous enclosed aqueduct in the Southern Hemisphere (22.5 m2 cross section). Built to divert water from the Orange River to the Great Fish River.
8 m2 cross section
Longest metro tunnel in Europe and longest tunnel in Turkey
Part of the 969 MW Neelum–Jhelum Hydropower Plant
7 m in diameter. Longest wastewater tunnel.
Longest metro/rapid transit circular line

Longest conventional railway tunnel. It is also the world's longest transit tunnel by geodetic distance; 55.782 km (34.661 mi) between the two portals. Total 151.84 km (94.35 mi) of broken out tunnels through solid rocks. Part of the NRLA.
74 m2; longest railway tunnel until 2016. Longest tunnel with an undersea section, running between Honshu and Hokkaido. Undersea section measures 23.3 kilometres (14.5 mi).
Longest metro/rapid transit tunnel until Guangzhou Metro Line 3 extension opened in 2010, crosses west to east under the Seoul Capital Area.
6 m2 cross section, longest tunnel until 1945. Part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Second longest railway tunnel until 2016. Longest underwater section, longest international tunnel (2×45 m2 + 1×18 m2), running between Folkestone, Kent, and Coquelles, Pas-de-Calais.
107 m2, part of the Suseo high-speed railway.
6.5 m in diameter

data.notes: Longest tunnel built to restore ecological balance. Transfers water from the Arpa to Lake Sevan to recover its level.

Diverts water from the Colorado River watershed to the South Platte River watershed for use in the Denver metropolitan area. Flows across Continental Divide. 4,465 feet (1,361 m) below the surface at its deepest point.
